;香港金融管理局建议改变香港的三级银行体系这是四十年来的首次，此举将完全消除最小类别的贷款机构。

;

;根据这些提议，金管局许可的 12 家现有所谓接受存款公司将被要求升级为香港事实上的央行周一表示，将在未来五年内加入其他级别（持牌银行和限制牌照银行）的行列。

;

;“此次审查旨在简化香港银行体系的结构，增强其金融体系。”金管局总裁余伟文在一份声明中表示：“金管局将在加强香港作为国际金融中心的地位方面发挥重要作用。”

;

;金管局将在 9 月 25 日之前收集有关这一想法的意见。如果获得批准，这将是对已有四年历史的三级银行体系的首次重大变革，将其简化为两级许可机制。

;

;存款公司通常由银行所有，为消费者提供服务金融、证券业务或其他商业贷款。他们的资本要求是三级中最低的，仅为25万港元（32,000美元），但可接受10万港元或以上的存款，且必须持有至少三个月。

;

;他们占

;

;约160家持牌银行构成香港银行体系的核心，占本地存款的99%。这些公司的最低资本要求为3亿港元。

;

;他们可以接受任何规模的存款，并提供全方位的银行服务。

;

;第二层有15家受限制的公司牌照银行主要是服务于资本市场的商业银行。他们需要拥有至少1亿港元的资本，并可吸收50万港元或以上的存款。

;

;根据新建议，持牌银行和有限制牌照银行的要求将保持不变。 12家三线企业可以提高资本要求以加入其他两类之一或自愿退出市场。

;

;岳表示，此举将“振兴存款类公司类别的机构，增强存款类机构的活力。”他们在开展业务和满足客户需求方面具有灵活性和效率。”

;

;持牌银行覆盖了香港99%的客户存款，而接受存款公司的覆盖率不到0.1%，而且牌照有限制金管局副总裁袁国恒表示，银行承担其余部分。

;

;“平衡监管和促进市场发展的考虑，我们应该从监管效率的角度审视现行的三级制度袁周一在一份声明中表示。

;

;通过将自己转变为有限制牌照银行，接受存款的公司将受益于摆脱客户存款需要在其存放三个月的限制。

;

;袁说：“这不仅为储户提供了更多选择，也使机构能够以更大的灵活性开展业务，从而促进市场发展和行业良性竞争。”

;

;多家存款公司与主要贷方有联系。其中包括大陆银行交通银行旗下的交通金融（香港）、台湾富邦银行旗下的富邦信贷（香港）以及大众银行旗下的大众金融。

;

;接受存款公司和有限制牌照银行的数量已从 1993 年的 200 家减少到目前的 27 家，而按资产计算的总市场份额也从 5.8% 下降到不足 1%。

;

;金管局自2009年起就没有收到接受存款公司的注册申请。

;

;“事实上，除了最低资本水平的要求外，金管局对这两类机构的监管要求[接受存款公司和有限制牌照银行]基本上是一样的。”袁说。

;礼来公司的一项实验性减肥镜头取得了最强劲的效果治疗，这是该公司努力主导新兴肥胖药物市场的又一推动力。

;

;根据数据，在最高剂量的药物治疗 48 周后，肥胖患者的体重平均减轻了 24.2% 《新英格兰医学杂志》周一发布的一项研究。公司资助的中期试验显示，接受最高剂量的患者中，有四分之一的患者体重减轻了 30% 或更多。

;

;“我们之前在一项试验中从未见过这样的结果——该研究的主要作者、耶鲁大学肥胖研究中心主任 Ania Jastreboff 说道。

;

;结果公布后，礼来公司股价在盘后交易中上涨，纽约下午 6 点 24 分，股价上涨 1.2%。

;

;凭借其减肥药物的预期，礼来公司已经成为世界上最有价值的制药商，礼来公司正努力在减肥疗法市场占据领先地位。到 2031 年，这一数字将达到 1500 亿美元。阻碍的竞争对手包括 Wegovy 制造商诺和诺德公司 (Novo Nordisk A/S)，以及来自辉瑞公司 (Pfizer Inc.)、阿斯利康公司 (AstraZeneca Plc) 和安进公司 (Amgen Inc.) 的一批实验药物。

;

;礼来 (Lilly) 的 Mounjaro，该公司旨在销售用于减肥的糖尿病药物，模仿称为 GLP-1 和 GIP 的激素。在早期的一项研究中，它帮助肥胖患者平均减轻了 21% 的体重；服用最高剂量药物的患者平均损失了 22.5%。

;

;军备竞赛的下一步，瑞他鲁肽模仿了第三种称为胰高血糖素的激素，其目标是刺激患者使用能量而不增加能量消耗。食欲。需要进行后期试验来确认数据。

;

;瑞他鲁肽“看起来确实可能是迄今为止最好的基于 GLP-1 的药物”，多伦多大学研究人员 Daniel Drucker 在肠道激素，在接受采访时说。他说，医生们正在寻找这些药物作为减肥“新时代的开始，我认为它将与减肥手术相媲美”。

;

;埃隆·马斯克使用的减肥药有缺点，医生说——谨慎行事

;

;Novo 还在开发 CagriSema，一种旨在增加体重减轻的药物，可与瑞他鲁肽竞争。 Novo 药物是 Wegovy 的活性成分索马鲁肽和一种模仿胰淀素（另一种与体重相关的激素）的药物的组合。

;

;在礼来公司的研究中，除了与 GLP 相关的常见恶心和呕吐之外，还出现了副作用-1药物包括瑞他鲁肽组中17名心律异常的患者，其中一名在服用抗呕吐药物后出现严重心律失常。哈佛大学、耶鲁大学和礼来公司的研究人员对 337 名患者进行了一项研究，其中两名服用安慰剂的患者出现心律异常。

;

;心率增加（也与减肥药物有关）在中途达到峰值通过审判并随后被拒绝。几乎所有服用瑞他鲁肽的患者体重都减轻了至少 5%，几乎三分之二服用最小剂量的患者体重减轻了 15% 或更多。

;

;因不良事件而退出的比例为根据剂量的不同，降糖效果在 6% 到 16% 之间。

;

;根据美国糖尿病大会上的演讲，瑞他鲁肽还改善了 2 型糖尿病患者的血糖控制，使一些患者的血糖水平降至正常范围。在加利福尼亚州圣地亚哥举行的协会会议。

;

;在一项非酒精性脂肪肝研究中，服用较高剂量的参与者至少 80% 的肝脏脂肪减少了 70%。

;

;最后阶段的研究将持续长达 80 周，以评估最大减肥效果，礼来公司产品开发高级副总裁 Jeff Emmick 在接受采访时表示。

;

;后期研究他说，试验还将研究对骨关节炎和睡眠呼吸暂停患者的影响，以便同时批准针对多种适应症的药物。

;日元的持续贬值引起了日本央行和日本央行的担忧日本政府，分析人士表示，物价上涨和公众不满情绪日益高涨，使得首相岸田文雄不太可能在今年举行大选。

;

;在疫情结束、经济恢复稳定的提振下今年早些时候，随着日本沐浴在上个月广岛七国集团会议的余辉中，人们普遍认为岸田正在为大选做准备——可能在夏末举行。

;<但最近几周的日元贬值似乎已经抵消了这些成就，并可能导致日本公众的物价进一步上涨，因为日本公众厌倦了成本上升，而工资基本保持不变。专家们一致认为，对于岸田来说，举行大选的风险太大。

;

;负责国际事务的财务省副大臣神田正人 (Masato Kanda) 周一表示，日元兑日元汇率下跌。美元和欧元“快速且片面”。周一上午，日元兑美元汇率在 143 左右波动，创 7 个月高点。

;

;日元兑英镑汇率为 182.66，为 2015 年 12 月以来的最高水平。兑欧元创 15 年来新高，兑澳元也同样走强。

;

;日本上次干预货币市场是在 9 月和 10 月，以抵消日元兑美元的下跌，神田证实政府可能会被迫再次采取行动，表示“不排除任何选择。”

;

;在 G7 成功、韩国关系改善的情况下，日本首相是否会提前举行大选？

;

;日元下跌富士通全球市场情报部首席政策经济学家马丁·舒尔茨表示，这是日本与美国和英国央行之间利差扩大的结果。但现在和日本上次干预时有一些重大区别。

;

;“上次他们干预时，是因为美元升值很快，国际局势不稳定，所以干预的效果出人意料。强大而有效的影响，”舒尔茨告诉《亚洲周刊》。 “但这次不一样。”

;

;日本央行坚持超低利率政策，而美联储和欧洲央行则遵循超低利率政策，抛售日元的压力随之而来。他表示，利率将持续上升。

;

;“除非日本央行确实改变政策，否则目前无能为力，”舒尔茨表示。 “他们一再表示不打算这样做，但很明显压力正在增加，很快就会成为他们能抵抗多久的问题。”

;

;日本出口商看到了更强劲的需求舒尔茨表示，汇率使他们的产品更便宜，而拥有海外子公司的大公司在将利润汇回本国时会获得意外之财，尽管日元疲软的最大受益者可能是入境旅游业。

;

;“今年我们已经看到入境旅游业的重大复苏，外国游客前往东京和京都等通常目的地以外的地方。”他说。

;

;上个月约有 190 万外国游客抵达日本，占 2019 年 5 月人数的近 69%，使该国有望在明年初恢复到大流行前的游客水平。

;

;尽管有政府援助，日本仍面临物价飞涨的困境

;

;然而，成本上升可能会抵消经济利益，因为十多年来，许多日本人在工资增长有限的情况下，还要与物价上涨作斗争。

;

;“对于政府来说，这很困难，”重村俊光说。东京早稻田大学政治学教授。 “企业很乐意从日元疲软中获利，但对家庭的影响使岸田更难召集选举。

;

;“几周前就有传言称他将在计划在夏末或初秋宣布大选，”他说。 “随着通货膨胀和对经济状况的日益担忧，他不可能进行这场赌博。

;

;“选举最早要等到明年，”重村说。他补充道，如果日本的经济问题持续存在，可能会再次推迟。

;一名男孩在年轻时接触色情内容，开始性侵犯他的妹妹他们的年龄分别为 10 岁和 11 岁。

;

;这名现年 25 岁的男子在认罪后于周一被新加坡高等法院判处 15 年半监禁和 12 下鞭刑。犯有一项对 16 岁以下未成年人进行性侵罪和严重法定强奸罪。另外 11 项指控（主要是针对他的姐妹的性犯罪）也被考虑在内。

;

;年长的受害者现年 24 岁，年轻的受害者 19 岁。

;

;没有人参与此事案件可以因禁言令而被命名。

;

;大部分犯罪行为发生在 2010 年至 2014 年期间，当时三兄弟与离婚的母亲住在一套两居室的住房委员会公寓中。

;

;然后，在 12 岁到 16 岁之间，这位在 10 岁时就接触过色情内容的兄弟，经常会在他的姐妹们睡在客厅的床垫上以及当他的母亲睡着时，以她们为目标。

;

;2010 年的一次，他的兄弟和 11 岁的年长受害者正在客厅观看电视上的儿童节目时，他对她进行了性侵犯。

;

;引用 2013 年的另一次事件，当时，被告在夜间对年长受害者进行性侵犯，检方表示，受害人“允许”她哥哥的性行为，因为她“由于多年来被告反复与她发生性行为而变得性欲强”。

;

;他即使当他开始占据公寓唯一的卧室时，他仍然继续犯罪，并要求他的姐妹们跟着他去那里。

;

;2014年，年长的受害者15岁时，她拒绝了她哥哥去他卧室的请求，因为她不想与他发生性关系。

;

;在他的坚持下，她态度软化了，因为她希望如果她让步，被告就不会再向她提出性要求。

;

;2014 年，被告强奸了当时 10 岁的年轻受害者，当时三兄弟正在看电视节目。

;

;鞭打是对新加坡老强奸犯最好的惩罚吗？

;

;年长的受害者，坐在他们前面的人并不知道这一行为。

;

;2017年，该男子参加了全日制学术课程，大部分时间都在校园里度过，减少了与姐妹们的互动

;

;然而，2020年6月，他猥亵了年长的受害者，并要求她与他发生性关系。 ”她的[辅导员]表示，她不想这样做，因为这些事件发生在很久以前，并且她担心她的母亲和姐姐发现被告对她做了什么，因为她还没有准备好与他们谈论这些事情副检察官 Niranjan Ranjakunalan 告诉法庭。

;

;然而，当年晚些时候，受害者在学校情绪崩溃，她再次被要求向警方报案。

;

;她于 2020 年 11 月 23 日这样做，被告于当天下午被捕。他的手机被没收，发现里面有四部淫秽影片的录音。

;

;该男子在精神卫生研究所接受检查，发现犯罪时没有精神疾病。他也没有智力障碍，也没有恋童癖。

;

;该男子的律师 Nakoorsha Abdul Kadir、Rasveen Kaur 和 Michelle Tang 表示，他们当事人的行为必须根据他的背景来考虑，包括他的行为方式。父母在他很小的时候就离婚了。

;

;“因此，[我们的客户]没有得到强有力的家庭支持，生活中也缺乏父亲形象。”

;

;“强奸犯不应该因为已经 50 岁而免遭鞭打”：新加坡总统

;

;考尔说，他的母亲也曾做出过让他对性亲密和性关系的扭曲理解永久化的行为。< /p>;

;“例如，[我们客户的]母亲经常带她遇到的不同性伴侣回家，[他]很清楚她与这些伴侣发生性行为。

;

;“[他]还相信他的母亲正在与他的“叔叔”发生性关系。他得出这个结论是因为他的母亲告诉孩子们称呼她当时的男友为‘叔叔’。”

;

;因此，被告相信他母亲的男友是他的亲戚，考尔说。

;

;律师表示，通过这些经历，该男子从小就对性亲密产生了扭曲的理解。

;

;辩护律师要求判处 13 至 15 年监禁，同时鞭打 12 下。

;

;“你怎么能？”：新加坡爷爷对儿子性侵女儿感到震惊

;

;副检察官 Christina Koh 寻求 15 至 17 年监禁以及 14 下鞭打。

;

;Koh 指出，受害者年龄较小，而且该男子在家庭环境中滥用信任，这些都是加重情节的因素。

;

;“而不是保护她免受伤害，他可以接触到[年轻的受害者]，侵犯了她在家中的安全避难所，”她说。

;

;法官 Hoo Sheau Peng 在宣判时表示，她“注意到”该男子当时还很年轻。

;

;鉴于他是初犯，她觉得法定最低鞭刑12下就足够了。

;如果说，李家超入主第一年的亮点就在于一个事件作为香港领导人，一月份重新开放了香港与中国大陆的边境。

;

;在担任行政长官七个月后，他得到了北京的祝福，首先向世界开放，然后向大陆开放尽管香港当时是最后一批放弃 Covid-19 限制的发达经济体之一，但这是具有里程碑意义的一步。

;

;

;“The government appears to believe that it doesn't have time for that, which is a dangerous position.”

;

;Speaking on condition of anonymity, a seasoned official suggested it was time for Lee to review the administration's priorities to tackle frustrations experienced by some government employees who were already complaining that they were caught in a “daily, endless pursuit” of meeting KPIs.

;

;On his diplomatic skills, Lee has won praise for improving the city's relationship with Beijing, but daunting challenges remain in repairing ties with the West.

;He has been eager to establish new ties with leaders in the Middle East and Asean countries, but recently faced a fresh round of pressure by the European Parliament over the “deterioration of fundamental freedoms” in Hong Kong.

;

;A key indicator will be whether Lee, who has been under United States sanctions since 2020, will attend an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit in San Francisco in November. Hong Kong joined the economic grouping in 1991, but US-sanctioned individuals cannot enter the country unless a waiver is granted.

;

;“Pressure from all sides is mounting on Lee, but he is not fighting the battle alone,” Lau said. “Hong Kong's uniqueness as an international hub with a common law system will only be further highlighted if geopolitical tensions continue to escalate.”

;CLP Holdings, which runs the larger of Hong Kong's two power utilities and has significant operations in Australia and India, has appointed the head of its Hong Kong unit Chiang Tung-keung as its new group CEO, making him the first Chinese national to hold the role.

;Richard Lancaster, 61, the current CEO who has been in the role for a decade, will be retiring at the end of September, CLP said in a filing to Hong Kong's bourse on Monday.

;Lancaster will remain as an executive director and become an adviser to the new CEO until early May next year, when he will step down from all positions at the group upon the conclusion of its next annual general shareholders meeting.

;“Mr Chiang, currently managing director of CLP Power Hong Kong Limited, has over 30 years of engineering, broad general management and regulatory experience in the power industry in CLP's core markets of Hong Kong and mainland China,” the company said.

;

;An electrical and electronic engineer by training, he has over three decades of engineering, general management and regulatory experience in the power industry in Hong Kong and mainland China.

;

;Chiang has had a key role in ensuring CLP's decarbonisation programme stays on track, which is important for Hong Kong to reach its goal of halving its carbon emissions by 2035 compared to the 2005 level, and becoming carbon neutral by 2050.

;

;Power generation accounts for around 60 per cent of the city's carbon emissions.

;

;Due to competing needs for clean electricity from provincial and municipal governments in Guangdong province, having central government support will be important for Hong Kong to secure sufficient low carbon energy from nearby facilities, such as nuclear and renewable power projects to be built in the region, Chiang said at the SCMP's Climate Change Hong Kong Summit last June.

;

;Chiang will be succeeded as managing director of CLP Power Hong Kong by Joseph Law Ka-chun, currently managing director responsible for mainland China operations. Law joined the company in 2001.

;The leadership transition comes as CLP Power Hong Kong and its peer HK Electric face pressure after blackouts left thousands of people without power in the past year. ;But democracies are driven by elections and political commitment that can wane over time, with allies not necessarily willing to step forward if a conflict breaks out in the future over Taiwan or another Indo-Pacific hotspot.

;

;Allied militaries would have to follow their political leaders of the day, according to Admiral Mike Gilday, chief of US naval operations, during the panel discussion hosted by the Centre for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington think tank.

;

;“With respect to [military-to-military], we're ready to go in whatever configuration the political, the governments, are willing to go,” Gilday said. “Whether it's two or three [countries] we have to be ready to flex and to adjust … Those are directions that we would execute accordingly.”

;

;The lack of communication between the US and Chinese militaries remained a concern, the officials said.

;

;“We will continue to articulate the rationale for why these are important, particularly as our forces increasingly rub up against one another and operate in closer proximity,” said Campbell, adding that China's reservations were deep and long-standing.

;

;“It is necessary, prudent, and indeed, expected that the United States and China take the necessary steps to have those lines of communication to deal with unexpected circumstances like a spy balloon that makes its way across the United States.”

;

;Additional reporting by Igor Patrick in Washington

;Russian President Vladimir Putin made a defiant televised address on Monday evening, saying he had deliberately let Saturday's 24-hour mutiny by the Wagner militia go on as long as it did to avoid bloodshed, and that it had reinforced national unity.

;

;The statement, his first on the issue since he spoke on Saturday promising to crush the mutiny, appeared intended to draw a line under an event that numerous Western leaders saw as exposing Putin's vulnerability since invading Ukraine 16 months ago.

;

;Wagner's fighters, led by Yevgeny Prigozhin, succeeded in taking control of the city of Rostov-on-Don with its military command centre steering the Ukraine campaign, and driving an armed convoy across Russia to within 200km (125 miles) of Moscow.

;

;“From the very beginning of the events, steps were taken on my direct instruction to avoid serious bloodshed,” Putin said.

;

;“Time was needed, among other things, to give those who had made a mistake a chance to come to their senses, to realise that their actions were firmly rejected by society, and that the adventure in which they had been involved had tragic and destructive consequences for Russia and for our state.”

;

;Putin made no mention of Prigozhin, who had demanded that Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and chief of the General Staff Valery Gerasimov, come to Rostov to speak to him.

;

;Prigozhin called for both of them to be dismissed.

;

;Nor did Putin mention any planned personnel changes at the defence ministry, although at around 11pm Moscow time he was shown on television addressing a meeting of heads of his security departments, including Shoigu.

;

;Putin may be weakened but outcome of Ukraine war remains unpredictable

;

;Prigozhin had said his men had been forced to shoot down helicopters that attacked them as they drove towards Moscow.

;

;Putin did allude to some bloodshed, but blamed it on Wagner: “The organisers of the mutiny, having betrayed their country, their people, also betrayed those whom they dragged into the crime. They lied to them, they pushed them to death: under fire, to shoot their own.”

;

;Putin thanked Wagner fighters and commanders who had stood down from the mutiny to avoid what he called “fratricidal bloodshed”, and said the vast majority of Wagner's members were patriots.

;

;He said those who decided not to sign contracts with the army under a defence ministry order could either relocate to Belarus or simply return to their families.

;

;Putin said all levels of society had taken “a firm, unambiguous position in support of the constitutional order”.

;

;“Everyone was united and rallied by the main thing,” he said, “responsibility for the fate of the Fatherland.”

;

;Russia says it is carrying out a “special military operation” in Ukraine to remove what it calls a potential threat against its own security from the Western-leaning government in Kyiv. Ukraine and the West described the February 2022 invasion as an unprovoked land grab.

;US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen plans to visit Beijing in early July for the first high-level economic talks with her new Chinese counterpart, people familiar with the scheduling said.

;Her trip was long anticipated but was put off until “the appropriate time”, Yellen said in April. The people discussed the timing and purpose of the trip on condition of anonymity, because the details have not been officially announced.

;

;In addition, a Biden administration executive order that would regulate and potentially cut off certain US investments in China is nearing completion and officials are aiming to have it ready as soon as late July, people familiar with the internal deliberations said.

;

;The Treasury chief would be the second US cabinet official to travel to Beijing after relations between the world's two biggest economies soured earlier this year. Secretary of State Antony Blinken just wrapped up his trip to China, where he met his counterpart and also had a short audience with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

;

;US and Chinese officials described the Blinken visit as productive and said the two sides had candid conversations on a range of issues.

;An administration official said Monday that Yellen's travel to China is not confirmed yet, while the executive order has not been finalised and does not yet have a timeline for issuance.

;In March, He Lifeng – a long-time confidant of Xi – became China's vice-premier responsible for economic policy, succeeding Liu He. That official is traditionally the counterpart to the US Treasury secretary.

;The Biden team for almost two years has been working on the executive order on US outbound investment in China, which would cover certain investments in semiconductors, artificial intelligence and quantum computing.

;Work on the draft order has ramped up in recent weeks, with the goal of publishing it as soon as late July, though the timing could slip into August, people familiar with the discussions said. The final details are also still being worked out.

; Tue, 27 Jun 2023 05:20:01 +0800 Wagner mutiny highlights Putin’s weakness, but outcome of Ukraine war remains unpredictablehttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3225359/wagner-mutiny-highlights-putins-weakness-outcome-ukraine-war-remains-unpredictable?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.27 04:00;
;;

;As the Ukraine war nears its 500th day, the key issue on the minds of international policymakers is what impact the extraordinary recent mutiny of the Wagner mercenary group will have on the conflict.

;

;The uprising, which exposed the growing internal fissures within the country, will do nothing to strengthen Russia's already faltering war efforts. Yet its wider impact, including for Russian President Vladimir Putin's hold on power, will not be fully clear for weeks to come. This despite some instant assessments – including that of former Russian prime minister Mikhail Kasyanov – that this is the “beginning of the end”.

;

;Putin's political longevity has been remarkable in the last quarter of a century. While he is clearly down and badly weakened, he cannot yet be counted out.

;

;One factor that will assist Putin is support from foreign countries, including staunch partners such as China and other friendly nations such as Turkey. China's foreign ministry said on June 25 that the country supported Russia in “protecting national stability”. Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang met Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Andrey Rudenko that day.

;

;The Wagner mutiny comes at a time when the initiative in the war was already very much with Ukraine as it moved forward with its counteroffensive. Kyiv will hope it can make even bigger gains than it had previously hoped for if disarray sets in more widely among pro-Moscow forces.

;

;Timeline of how Russia's mercenary revolt unfolded

;

;If Putin remains in power, which seems most likely for the foreseeable future, and the Russian war effort continues apace, the most likely scenario remains the conflict following the trajectory of a war of attrition, albeit with significant twists and turns. This seems especially likely while both sides are still prepared to expend massive resources.

;

;Some Western intelligence sources estimate that more than 200,000 Russian soldiers have already died on the battlefield, one of the chief gripes of Wagner leader Yevgeny Prigozhin. This illustrates the terrible human price Putin is prepared to have his nation pay in pursuit of his war objectives. Meanwhile, the West has committed vast sums to Ukraine in aid and military support.

;

;Historically, wars tend to end when one side imposes its will on the other on the battlefield and then at the negotiating table, or when both sides embrace a compromise they deem preferable to fighting. While one of these outcomes could emerge – for instance, if the Ukrainian counteroffensive makes spectacular gains or the Putin regime implodes – this appeared highly uncertain at the time of writing amid fast-moving events in late June.

;

;While a continued war of attrition could imply a degree of stability in the conflict, the events of recent days show this is not true and the level and range of risks actually remain exceptionally high. This is why the outcome remains so unpredictable, a factor not helped by Russia's reckless sabre-rattling around its potential use of nuclear weaponry and disregard for nuclear power sites.

;

;Pessimistic as this prospect of a continued war of attrition might seem, with the human cost – including for millions of refugees – largest of all, there are at least two other plausible outcomes. First, there could be a slim but significant window of opportunity for peace talks opening up, especially with heavier casualties taken by each side.

;

;Belarus strongman sows future peril with Wagner PR success

;

;Although neither Moscow nor Kyiv is showing strong signs of wanting to negotiate, this could change. On Ukraine's side, for instance, if its much-anticipated counteroffensive yields little fruit, pressure could grow to explore a peace deal. There would be a great deal of opposition to this, of course, but a pathway could be found.

;

;For instance, key Western leaders could highlight to Ukraine that, during the Cold War, the US-led alliance did not recognise Soviet control of the three Baltic states. Ultimately, these countries emerged free and democratic after the end of the Cold War. The potential parallel with those parts of Ukraine now occupied by pro-Moscow forces could be strengthened with generous Western construction assistance and security guarantees for Kyiv.

;

;A peace deal could also have growing utility for Russia and Putin – should he remain in power – as he fashions his political strategy for potential re-election in next spring's presidential election. Putin could seek to argue, despite the manifest failures of Moscow's military campaign, that Russia's mission has been accomplished with the seizure of significant slices of Ukrainian territory.

;

;Another factor that could increase prospects for peace is the growing interest of China in the conflict. President Xi Jinping, who has already set out a vague peace plan, has the most influence within Russia of any world leader.

;

;However, Putin's growing weakness also raises the worst-case scenario of further escalation of violence. If he chooses to raise the stakes, the conflict could even escalate beyond Ukraine to involve Nato countries.

;

;While this still seems unlikely to many, it cannot be dismissed given the volatility of the situation. The transatlantic alliance is doing what it can to support Ukraine without getting itself entangled in direct military confrontation, but miscalculation is a real concern.

;

;Such an outcome is still not the central scenario, though. While Putin remains in power, the most likely outcome is that a war of attrition grinds on.
